results.notes:
Cortinarius mucosus (Bull.) J. Kickx f., Cortinariaceae, Agaricales.
Local name: Паутинник слизистый
Cap: 4-10cm convex up to flattened, margins curved under for young unit, colour from orange-yellow or brownish-orange up to ochre-brown with dying. It is slimy in wet weather and glossy when dry time. It looks as covered with 1-3mm thick glue.
Gills: almost attached, close; colour from white or pinkish-white up to ochre-brown.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, white and sticky when young, 1.5-2.5cm thick, enlarged down up, often has orange hairy ring under a cap margin and sometimes irregular dull orange-yellow scaly rings on the stalk.
Veil: loose and white as cotton, then hairy and reddish (remnants)
Edibility: good after boiling (published in Russian sites)
Habitat: small groups in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Season: July – September.
results.location_name: Borovoye National Park, Akmola District, Kazakhstan

results.notes: This is on pine-tree stump

Cap: 5-10 cm, convex up to broadly convex, then flat with wavy margins when old; orange-yellow with light margins and darker reddish central part; surface smooth.
Gills: attached with pinching out to the stalk, close up to crowded, narrow with short and very short intermediate gills, colour yellowish-white or pinkish-white.
Stalk: 8-14cm long, 1-1.6cm thick, fibrous when old, irregular coloured yellowish-white with reddish threads.
Edibility: no data.
Habitat: rare kind, on intensive rotten pine stump in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September.

results.notes:
Two small almost round white tiny stipe fungi resting in Eucalyptus Rain forest soil and covered by leaves. The two fungi were about a meter apart.

results.notes:
On shale bedrock with Dimelaena oreina. Thallus composed of peltate, imbricate squamules 1mm or usually much less, dark reddish brown above, dark below, with marginal elongated soralia and a thick single attachment. Algae a cyanobacteria and seemingly green algae as well. Apothecia absent.

Peltula bolanderi is the only species that is anywhere near this small and this specimen doesn’t seem to match. I have a hunch the genus is wrong.

Interestingly I found two lichenicolous fungi growing on the thallus. One looks like standard vegetative hyphae of Lichenostigma, which was abundant on the Dimelaena oreina nearby. The other consisted only of small black perethecia (pseudothecia?) occurring between the margins of overlapping thallii. I’ll post this one separately, it seems to be a species of the genus Endococcus.
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Growing on Lecidea atrobrunnea group Peltula (observation 253285).

Pseudothecia appear as black cone-like protrusions between margins of imbricate squamules, 0.1-0.2mm in diameter. Pseudothecia is globose, with thick black outer wall, red-brown internally. When crushed they open in a PacMan shape. Outer wall is I+Blue.

Asci globose, spores 1-septate, hyaline to slightly grey colored, ellipsoid with narrowed ends and constricted septum. Average size 17.0×6.5µm (19.2×6.5, 17.4×6.9, 16.8×6.5, 15.9×6.4, 15.8×6.0, 17.1×6.7)

results.notes:
Description (macromorphological):

Pileus: Not larger than 8 mm diameter; first ovoid, later expanded with small umbo; at first entirely covered with vinaceous red brown velum, which later breaks up into small, dark, hispid, fairly spikey, erect quamules on the outer half, center stays dark; surface very fine radially filamentose-fibrillose; surface whitish with lilac tinge; margin appendiculate, pileipellis overhanging; no discolouration after bruising.

Lamellae: L +/- 28, l: 3; crowded, free from stipe, very narrow, slightly ventricose; margin even, maybe finely fimbriate (L. 60x); white to cream.

Stipe: Upto 1.5x the diameter of the pileus; centrally placed, very thin, tapering towards the pileus, flexuous; covered with the same squamules as on the pileus; surface at the apex bald, from there below over entire length finely fibrillose; apex lighter, whitish, towards the base gradually vinaceous; sometimes with very fine, dark ring zone at about ¼ below the pileus.

Context: Very thin, whitish, not changing colour.

Smell/taste: Smells slightly musky, a bit spermatic after bruising; no flavor documented.

Ecology: In a plant pot with Pyrrosia lingua var. lingua in a botanical greenhouse of the Hortus Botanicus, Leiden, Netherlands.
results.location_name: Hortus Botanicus, Leiden, Zuid-Holland, Netherlands

results.notes:
Boletus edulis Bull., Boletaceae, Agaricales. (King Bolete, Белый гриб или гриб-боровик).
Cap: 8-20cm wide, convex up to broadly convex; surface is smooth brown or yellowish-brown, minor reddish-brown, sometimes old cap crossed with radial and concentrically cracks (fast change from wet up to hot and dry time). Odour is fragrant. Flesh is white. Tubes: attached, often sunken up around old stalk, colour from white or yellowish-white up to greenish-yellow. Stalk: 8-18cm long, colour whitish up to cream or dull light brown; 3-7cm thick, enlarged down; stalk surface looks as covered with fine fabric as indistinct spider web.
Habitat: common kind in this forest; often small group or single (cause intensive hunting for this kind) scattered in pine-tree forest with birches (sometimes between pine and birch).
Edibility: delicious (several methods of cooking).
July – August.

results.notes:
Leccinum vulpinum Watling, Boletaceae, Agaricales.
This is a common kind in this location and it is far away from aspen, sometimes between pine and birch, usually nearby pine-trees. It was studied when abundant (bruising and age discolouring – lots of photos). (Local name: Красноголовик, «Подосиновик», Красноголовик сосновый)
Cap: 6-18cm convex up to broadly convex; surface fine velvety as old skin, minor smooth in wet weather; orange-red and orange (young), pale brownish-orange or pale red-orange (adult) up to dull orange-yellow or brownish-yellow and sometimes with a net of cracks (old and drying up). Age discolouring is common, especially with sun light, so there are red spots and strips under branches and leaves. Odour is weak and pleasant. Flesh is white and the older the softer and darker; after damage it bruising pink or light red (young), purplish-pink (adult), purplish-grey or grey (old and drying up); the drier weather, the slower bruising.
Tubes: attached (sometimes almost free when very old, cause a ring depression under a cap around stalk), colour from whitish up to brownish-white or very light dull brown, sometimes with irregular dull reddish-brown spots (old).
Stalk: 6-16cm long, 1.5-3cm thick and enlarged down; whitish with tiny projections, projections colour is pinkish-white then brownish-gray or gray; bruising pink or light red (young), purplish-pink (adult), purplish-grey or grey (old); sometimes the cutting of an old base is light greenish-blue.
Habitat: small group nearby pine-trees or their stumps, sometimes between pine and birch wood.
Edibility: tasty.
Season: June – August.

results.notes:
Growing in large numbers on a pile of wood chips in a forest clearing. Most were dried and in poor condition. Habitat photos were difficult, as the sun had already set. Discoloration on the stipe is noted.

The fruit body, itself, is extreme sturdy. The stipe, despite being exceptionally long, snaps in two rather than bending. Grows gregariously, but with no more than 4-8 fruiting from the same patch of myc. Noticeable umbo at the center of the pileus, and partial veil remnants on the caps’ margins.

results.notes: I found it after it had been dropped by a squirrel, so I don’t have the base of the stem. Found near beech, shagbark hickory, red oak and sugar maple. Pores depressed at the stem and bruising dark blackish-blue. Cut context off-white to buff, not very yellowish. Bruising blue only very slightly and slowly in the cap near the apex of the stipe. Stem pinkish and without pruina. Very slightly reticulate at the apex. This is a pretty good match for “B. bicolor” var. borealis other than the context not being very yellow.

Leccinum duriusculum (Schulzer ex Kalchbr.) Singer, Boletaceae, Agaricales. (Local name: Подберёзовик жестковатый)
Cap: 5-12cm convex up to broadly convex, smooth; dark brown or chocolate brown. Odour is fragrant. Flesh is white and not bitter also fresh.
Tubes: attached when young, colour whitish up to pale yellowish-brown with a ring depression under a cap around stalk when old, not bitter.
Stalk: 8-15cm long with tiny projections as darker dots, light grey or brownish-gray up to dull brown and yellowish-brown with black dots, minor dark grey when old and drying up; 1.5-3.5cm thick, enlarged down, often up to almost bulbous base; old one is fibrous and stiff.
Habitat: small groups or single scattered near birches inside pine-tree forest, sometimes on hummocks in wet boggy mixed forest.
Edibility: good (several methods of cooking).
June – September.

results.notes:
Growing from wood of rotten hardwood logs, found in small groups at three places.

Caps are small, 15 mm or less. Odor not checked. Dried material: caps and stems black, gills gray with whitish edges.

Diagnostic characters to navigate within the section:

(1) Hyphae of the pilepellis diverticulate? – YES
(2) Hyphae of the cortical layer of the stipe diverticulate – YES
(3) Cheilocystidia forked or diverticulate? – NO
(4) Pleurocystidia present? – NO
(5) Most spores in the range 7-9 × 3.5-5, though there are some that are up to 12 microns long (borne from less than 4-spored basidia).

Smith’s “Typicae” key leads to M. alnicola, perhaps M. parabolica, if we relax the spore size. Robich leads to M. leptocephala; perhaps M. abramsii , again if we relax the spore size. All these species are 4-spored, with leptocephala only mentioned to occur with 2- or 3-spored basidia. Our collection has a striking mix of all these, and even 1-spored basidia.

Other measurements: basidia 27-30 × 8-9; cheilocystidia 29-36 × 10-14; hyphae of the pileipellis 3.5 microns wide.

results.notes:
I recorded this as occurring on wood. The photo appears to show leaf litter clinging to the one stipe base. So I’m guessing then habitat was actually wood with adhering leaf litter.

Coal-tar odor, similar to Tricholoma odorum but not as strong.

Singerocybe adirondackensis was the name used for this (or a similar species) last year. I’m guessing the status hasn’t changed. Although I see that Index Fungorum lists Singerocybe phaeophthalma, which Champignins du Quebec also uses for a fungus matching this description. But IF lists Clitocybe phaeophthalma var. werneri as a recent synonym of Singerocybe adirondackensis. IF also lists Clitocybe phaeophthalma (sans werneri) as a currently valid species name. Several of the MO posts using this name come form Europe. I surmise that Clitocybe phaeophthalma (sans werneri) is a valid European name.

Therefore, this must be Singerocybe adirondackensis…. I think.

results.notes:
Fongarium: cKc0581
Date: 26.IX.2016
Biotopes: pousse sur bois pourri, débris ligneux ;

Macromorphologie
Basidiome 20-50 mm de hauteur, 15-45 mm Ø, piriforme, subglobuleux, ovoïde, ogival à submamelonné au-dessus, parfois plissé à la jonction de la partie élargie et la base stipitiforme atténuée qui est petite à proéminente selon la forme du basidiome, avec nombreux rhizomorphes distincts, tenaces et blancs, souvent radiants d’une base à l’autre, à exopéridium pâle puis brun fauvâtre, typiquement brun rouille plus foncé avec l’âge, parfois jaunâtre, lisse ou avec quelques petites épines dispersées au-dessus au début, puis se brisant par plaques aréolées plus foncées qui se divisent en plus petites unités qui deviennent de fins granules ou écailles polygonales au sec, relativement rugueux et persistants ;
Sac sporifère à endopéridium papyracé, ferme, lisse, blanchâtre puis brun-jaune, s’ouvrant par un grand pore apical souvent irrégulier et tardif, avec sous-glèbe spongieuse, constamment blanche à maturité, à chambres très petites ;
Glèbe blanche et ferme au début, puis jaune verdâtre et spongieuse, brun olive et poudreuse à maturité ;
Pseudocolumelle bien formée ;

Monographies:
- Smith, Alexander H. Puffballs and their allies in Michigan, Ann Arbor, The University of Michigan Press, 1951, 187 p.
- Pegler, D. N., Laessøe, T., Spooner, B. M. British Puffballs Earthstars and Stinkhorns: An account of the British Gasteroid Fungi, Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, 1995, 145 p.

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

results.notes: This one has me completely stumped. When I first spotted in from a distance, on a fallen log, I thought it was Stereum complicatum, but on closer inspection I was surprised to see the fertile surface covered with “matted hairs”, reminiscent of the orange mat ozonium of Coprinellus domesticus. Then I wondered if I had a mixed collection here. However, under magnification it appears that the “hairs” are integral to these specimens. If you zoom in on the upper right corner of the in situ image (# 9105) you can see what I’m talking about. I tweezed away the hairs and a smooth fertile surface like that of S. ostrea was revealed. Anyone have an idea? I’m just guessing that this may be in the Stereum genus.

Chapeau 40-80 mm de hauteur x 30-60 mm Ø, lorsque fermé, 30-80 (100) mm Ø, après expansion, subglobuleux, ellipsoïde à ovoïde puis campanulé, largement conique à convexe, squamuleux au centre à sublisse, gris-brun au début, puis gris, à marge striée à irrégulièrement plissée, se fendant et se déchirant souvent avec l’âge ;
Lames libres, larges, très serrées, blanches puis grises à brun grisâtre, noires à la fin, rapidement déliquescentes ;
Pied 70-150 × 8-20 mm Ø, égal ou élargi vers la base, soyeux-fibrilleux, blanchâtre, souvent avec une petite zone annuliforme marginée sur la partie inférieure ;

results.notes:
This weird Agrocybe is fairly new to science. It has been described by my Dutch colleague Marijke Nauta in 2003! I have seen it many times, but never had the chance to take photos. So here it finally is.

Easily recognized by its pale brown, rugose to rugulose pileus, which may or may not have white, filamentose scales, its cream to pale brown, crowded lamellae and a pale stipe with a large, white, pendulous annulus and an enlarged base with rhizoids. Grows particularly on woodchips and mulch.

Description (macromorphology):

Pileus: 30-80 mm; irregular, ovoid, later campanulate to convex; at first strongly rugose, later smoother, the outer half often rugulose; surface is smooth, shiny, slightly tacky, later dry; margin sometimes appendiculate; covered in white, filamentose velum which breaks up into floccules and stays on the pileus not unlike an Amanita, especially on younger specimens, less floccules on mature specimens; colour pale brown, later paler outer half with darker center, some young specimens have a warmer brown tone.

Lamellae: L: not recorded, l: 3; numerous, thin, crowded, narrow, free from the stipe to adnexed, sometimes slightly running over the apex; cream to pale brown when young, later café-au-laît.

Stipe: Upto 100 mm; irregularly cilindrical to appressed, dry, fibrillose, soft texture, white basal mycelium, sometimes subperonate/volvate; pale brown; large, filamentose, white, pendulous annulus, smooth on top, finely fibrillose on the underside, tears easily, sometimes as decoration on the pileal margin (appendiculate); base slightly to obviously bulbous, with rhizoids.

Context: Firm, thick in the center of the pileus, quite soon partially hollow in the stipe, then stuffed with loose hyphae; dark line above the hymenium; white to slightly brownish in the cortex of the stipe when mature, sericeous.

Smell/Taste: No to very slightly mushroomy smell; inconspicuous to slightly “bitter” tasting.

Ecology: Alone, in groups or cluster, or in a semi-fairy ring on a woodchip path of a dog walking area, probably broadleaf chips, since the mycelium of Chlorocibora spec. is everywhere, with Salix spec. standing in the vicinity. Sharing the habitat with Leucocoprinus cepistipes.

Code: Bot_1008/2016_IMG1461

Habitat: River bank, wood edge, Picea abies dominant, next to a trail, almost flat terrain, quite-open place, partly sunny, air and ground humid place; calcareous, alluvial, sandy ground; exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 565 m (1.850 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil, possibly buried wood in the last phase of disintegration.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, left bank of river Soča, somewhat downstream from farmhouse Maselc, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Guepinia helvelloides is not a rare find in Trenta valley. However, this time the find was extremely large, exceeding in size all data in literature I am aware off. Usually the sporocarps are about 5-6 cm tall. Interestingly, also spore width does not fit into expected limits. Spores are significantly larger, so one could suspect a wrong determination of the find. However, to my knowledge, there is nothing similar to this mushroom growing in Slovenia.

Growing solitary, two pilei fuzzed at the base; dimensions of the larger 11.5 × 10 cm across and 10.5 cm tall; stipe rudimentary, about 2 cm long and 1.5 cm in diameter, partly hollow; SP white, oac909.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
